text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English
speaker: Dan

text: From BBC Learning English
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Dan and joining me today is Neil, hey Neil.
Hello Dan, what's on the agenda today?
Well, I’ll give you a clue.
speaker: Dan

text: It's something that makes the world go round,
but it doesn't really exist.
In fact, if we all stopped believing in it,
it would have no use at all.
What is it?
I haven't got a clue.
OK, how about this?
Hmm, money.
Yep
speaker: Neil

text: And not just any money,
we're talking about cryptocurrency.
Currency is the money that’s being used
speaker: Currency

text: in a given country at a certain time.
speaker: Dan

text: But what about the crypto part?
Well, crypto is a prefix, meaning hidden or secret.
It comes from the word cryptic,
which means mysterious or difficult to understand.
You may have heard about the most popular cryptocurrency
at the moment, the Bitcoin.
Well I’ve certainly heard the name,
speaker: Neil

text: but I can't say I know what it is.
First, our quiz question.
When was the Bitcoin cryptocurrency first created?
Well, I think 2004 may have been a little early,
speaker: Dan

text: and I think 2013 could be a little late,
so the smart money's on 2009.
We'll see if you'll write later on in the show.
So, Bitcoin, what do you know about it?
Well, I know it's a digital currency,
speaker: Dan

text: so presumably you can use it online to buy things.
You are right on the money, which means correct, both times.
speaker: legal tender.

text: Bitcoin is just like any other currency, except for two things.
First, it's not printed by governments or banks,
which means that it's not legal tender.
Legal tender means the official money
that can be used within a country.
speaker: cryptic

text: So that means we can't use it to pay taxes or settle debts, right?
Exactly.
speaker: fluctuates

text: Governments won't recognize it as an official currency,
although it acts just like one.
You can use it to buy items from anyone who will accept it
and its value fluctuates.
Fluxuates means changes in level or amount.
And what's the second thing?
Ah, the second thing is that bitcoin is a digital currency,
speaker: Dan

text: meaning that with the exception of a few tokens,
it largely exists online only.
You can't carry a load of Bitcoins around in your pocket.
Well, that makes a nice change.
Oh dear, Neil.
speaker: Dan

text: Was that a money pun?
Terrible.
So, if it's a digital only currency, where do new ones come from?
Can't I just say that I've got a million of them and make myself rich?
Well, no.
speaker: Dan

text: You see, even though Bitcoin is not regulated by a bank or government,
it still has a process that stops people from cheating.
There are only two ways to get Bitcoins.
You either trade them from someone or you go mining.
Ah, wait, I've heard about this.
This is when you use your computer to run calculations
which verify other Bitcoin transactions.
You get rewarded for this work by earning Bitcoins.
Yep! It’s money for old rope,
speaker: Dan

text: which means it's an easy way to earn money.
Wow, I'm going to start mining immediately.
Well, you wouldn’t be the only one!
speaker: Dan

text: Bitcoins' value has recently gone up quite a lot
and this has caused a lot of interest.
In fact, one stock exchange in Chicago has begun trading
in Bitcoin futures contracts.
A futures contract?
speaker: Dan

text: What's that?
I'll let BBC correspondent Rory Ketlin-Jones explain that.
The futures contract, a bet on where the currency will be a month from now,
soared above $18,000.
That means investors believe Bitcoin,
which started the year worth under $1,000,
will continue to rise in value, albeit at a slower rate.
But at the big banks, there's still plenty of skepticism
about the currency.
Soared in this context means increased very quickly.
speaker: Soared

text: So now big investors are betting on the value of Bitcoin in the future.
Yes, but he also mentioned that the banks have a lot of skepticism.
That's a doubt that something is real or true.
In this case, whether Bitcoin is reliable or not.
Maybe it’s best I don’t get involved then.
speaker: Neil

text: After all, a fool and his money are soon parted.
Well, you don't have to be skeptical about the answer to our quiz.
We know that for a fact.
I asked you when the Bitcoin cryptocurrency was first created.
And I said 2009.
speaker: Dan

text: And you were right.
Well done.
Shall we go over the vocabulary again?
First, we had currency.
That's the money being used in a given country at a certain time.
Name three currencies and their countries, Dan.
OK.
speaker: Neil

text: But for Thailand,
Rupi for India, and my favourite, Metacal for Mozambique.
Next, we had cryptic.
Something which is cryptic is mysterious or difficult to understand.
For example, what do rich people need?
Poor people have.
And if you eat it, you die.
Hmm, a cryptic riddle indeed.
I'll have to think about that.
Then we had legal tender.
That's the official money that can be used within a country.
The euro is legal tender within Spain.
But what was the legal tender before that?
Wasn't it the per seater?
Then we had fluctuates.
speaker: fluctuates

text: If something fluctuates, it changes in amount or level.
The stock market fluctuates.
But my love for my family never does.
Then we had sword, which means increased very quickly.
It's used with this meaning in the context of money,
prices and statistics.
Finally, we had skepticism.
Skepticism is doubt that something is real or true.
What sort of things are people skeptical about, Neil?
Some people think that human activity
hasn't caused climate change.
They are skeptical.
And that brings us to the end of today's six-minute English.
Don't forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages.
And we'll see you next time.
Goodbye.
Goodbye.
